questions.question_text: Campus users report a poor wireless experience. An engineer investigating the issue notices that in high-density areas, the wireless clients fail to switch the AP to which are automatically connected. This sticky client behavior is causing roaming issues. Which feature must the engineer configure?

discussion.content:
A - "Optimized roaming resolves the problem of sticky clients that remain associated to access points that are far away"

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-1/configuration-guide/b_cg81/b_cg81_chapter_010001110.pdf
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-1/configuration-guide/b_cg81/b_cg81_chapter_010001110.pdf

Selected Answer: C
qos c.

Selected Answer: B
Most services are in the cloud. This may be important information, users and services are separated by WAN (no QOS, best effort only) so enabling QOS only on WiFi part of data path may not improve user experience as fast roaming does. Vote B

Selected Answer: C
“The primary goal of QoS is to provide priority including dedicated bandwidth, controlled jitter and latency (required by some real-time and interactive traffic), and improved loss characteristics.”
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-5/config-guide/b_cg85/quality_of_service.html#qos

Fast secure roaming is particularly useful for maintaining connectivity but doesn’t address prioritization of traffic types.

Selected Answer: B
Really bad question. Depends where is the Internet breakout. Internet = no QOS, useless to set that if direct access to internet on LAN. If not - traffic over wan - might then help

Stuck between B and C here, but I'm going with B ultimately because I think the key here is "moved most services to the cloud"...meaning out on the Internet. QoS markings cannot be honored out on the Internet, as MoD82 alluded to, so the markings get dropped once the packets leave your private WAN. Alternatively, a fast roaming handoff will improve the wireless experience. A tricky one from Cisco, but I think the best choice here is B.

Selected Answer: B
could only be B, QoS ends at WAN

Selected Answer: C
Clearly C.

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C

Once the phrase "Real Time Communications" was mention which encompasses Voice & Video. QoS is required.

Selected Answer: C
QOS (c)

QoS is configured at the WLAN (SSID).
Of course it helps when you have a WLAN for voice QoS and a separate VLAN for data (best effort), but QoS is not something that you 'enable' at the wireless network.

Roaming can be tricky for real-time communication when no fast secure roaming amendments have been configured.

For that reason I opt for answer B

yeah I think is QoS, you can fast roaming but if your applications like video/audio its giving delays or interruptions even if you are not roaming, then means the AV traffic is being combined with normal traffic. QoS is for me.
I think it is QoS
it could be correct if we consider ISE being moved to the cloud
Shouldn't the answer be QoS?

questions.question_text: An enterprise has moved most services to the cloud, including email applications and real-time communication. Which feature must be enabled on the wireless network to improve the user experience?

An enterprise is using two wireless controllers to support the wireless network. The data center is located in the head office. Each controller has a corporate
WLAN configured with the name Copr-NET392267230WLC-1 and Corp-NET68371638WLC-2. The APs are installed using a round-robin approach to load balance the traffic. What should be changed on the cofiguration to optimize roaming?

choices.D: Place the access points per floor on the same controller.
choices.A: Use the same WLAN name for the corporate network on both controllers.
choices.C: Move the controllers to an external data center with higher internet speeds.
choices.B: Move all access points to one controller and use the other as N+1 HA.

comments.content:
I agree.
They are talking about WLAN Names (SSIDs) here.
Not the Mobility Group Name

discussion.content:
"For a wireless client to seamlessly roam between mobility group members (WLCs), a given WLAN SSID and security configuration must be consistent across all WLCs comprising the mobility group"
Enterprise Mobility 8.5 Design Guide, Ch2, p2-57
So the WLANs' names should be the same, the answer is A

Selected Answer: A
roaming requires same SSID

A is the correct one. To optimize roaming:
Using a shared SSID on both controllers allows devices to perceive the network as a single entity and roam seamlessly between APs.

Placing APs per floor on one controller only benefits that floor and does not resolve the issue of differing SSIDs between controllers.
Moving all APs to one controller and using the other as N+1 HA removes load balancing and does not address the SSID mismatch.
Answer: B
I'd suggest A because of inter-floor roaming and bleed-through.

comments.content: Seems like the WLCs are not in the same mobility domain so if the WLANs will have the same names - roaming will be slow. I think the best option os to configure HA SSO, so my answer is B.

discussion.content:
Answer: BE

Cisco 8821 phones are clients that support CCKM.
CCKM caches clients' PMK for 1 hour (good for voice calls) and works inter-controller, but this require that the WLCs know each other: Mobility Group
B & E i think

Selected Answer: BE
BE are the correct choice

Selected Answer: BE
like an another comments

comments.content: I don't think tagging voice traffic as best-effort is a valid choice, so for me C is not correct.
best effort is the QoS default setting, you should not combine sensible traffic like video and audio with the normal traffic. C is not an answer for me. Answer B and E for me. correct

discussion.content: Answer: C & E

questions.question_text: The wireless team must configure a new voice SSID for optimized roaming across multiple WLCs with Cisco 8821 phones. Which two WLC settings accomplish this goal? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Configure AVC profiles on the SSID.
choices.C: Use AVC to tag traffic voice traffic as best effort.
choices.E: Use Cisco Centralized Key Management for authentication.

questions.question_text: Which two criteria must be considered when conducting an outdoor bridge site survey? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Cisco, in their official documentation, talk about weather and fresnel zone. Power lines do not affect line of sight and wireless signals and the Near-far problem has no connexion to wireless bridges. Source : https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/technology/mesh/8-0/design/guide/mesh80/m_site-preparation-and-planning.html#ID3455
Weather and Fresnel zone are important for outdoor radio survey

Selected Answer: BE
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/technology/mesh/7-3/design/guide/Mesh/Mesh_chapter_0100.html#ID3731
The official cert guide CCNP Enterprise wireless design and implementation makes no mention of this subject.

Selected Answer: BE
the answer is BE

Selected Answer: BE
According to Cisco ENWLSD Course, it is B and E.

Selected Answer: BE
weather and fresnel zone
B and E are correct

Selected Answer: BE
B and E are correct

Selected Answer: BE
Weather can degrade a mesh link. A Fresnel zone is an imaginary ellipse around the visual line of sight between the transmitter and receiver. It could encounter an obstruction in the Fresnel area which degrading the signal.

Selected Answer: BE
I agree with antmich
Answer: B e E
Answer: B y E
